children.text: Meredith Martin: Awesome. Okay. For the record, I'm sorry I was mean, Andy. It was best.
Andy Byers: Don't worry.

Andy Byers: I've dealt with… I've dealt with people who are actually mean. I once had to tell someone that if they contacted one of my team members again, I would have to ban their email address from accessing our support system.
Meredith Martin: That was a fun… that was a fun one to deal with.
Andy Byers: I do.

Meredith Martin: I did follow up, speaking of support system, I did follow up with Scholastica. Again, you probably are now CC'd on that ticket, and I was like, is there a number we can use to call you? Like, you did not answer the question, this is not helpful at all, so maybe I gave them my number, and…
Andy Byers: Yeah, I'm… I'm, like, 99% sure that they'll come back with, it's not possible.
Meredith Martin: To migrate to English?
Andy Byers: Yeah.
Andy Byers: Basically, the XML has this path in it with the images, like figure 1, figure 2.
Meredith Martin: Yeah.

Andy Byers: asset slash, then, whatever the figure is called, and you'd expect to be able to sort of find that. Yeah. But there is no way that I can figure out to get it. And when you look at the HTML, as they said, it's this weird sort of Amazon S3 bucket link, and it's like, well, how do I translate one into the other? That's what I want to know, you know? Yeah.
Meredith Martin: Yeah.
Andy Byers: I suspect we're gonna have to harvest them ourselves, manually. Well, not manually, we'll write a script to do it, but, that's…
Meredith Martin: What a pain in the ass.
Andy Byers: next step, in case we can't make this work.
Meredith Martin: Yeah.
Andy Byers: answer for us.
Meredith Martin: Yeah, okay.
Andy Byers: first.
Andy Byers: Yeah, so I put together, like, a very basic, site, black and white, using the old logo, and we can use this to launch, or we can completely hide this if you want it to be submission only.
Andy Byers: But it basically has the content imported onto it.
Andy Byers: So the issues are there…
Andy Byers: I need to tweak that display a little bit. The issues are there.
Andy Byers: And… We've got the submission page, which we'll… I'll show you the settings for today, how to manage those…
Meredith Martin: You can go and change, yeah.
Andy Byers: Yeah, contact will show you to add contacts as well. So yeah, I've imported the article metadata.
Meredith Martin: Okay.
Andy Byers: You can see the abstract and keywords and stuff all showing up.
Andy Byers: I can, at this point, import the PDF as well for download, and I can import the XML, and it will display properly, but without the images, it looks terrible.
Meredith Martin: How about…
Andy Byers: issue.
Meredith Martin: I bet. Okay, so we gotta solve that.
Andy Byers: Yeah, so once we've… once they've given us a solution, we'll be fine to get the actual files, the article files, into this site.
Meredith Martin: for coal.
Andy Byers: Yeah, so… Well, we're gonna go through, basically, today.
Andy Byers: You know, how to make changes to this site and play around with it.
Meredith Martin: And it's the… it's the live version of your website, so…
Andy Byers: Once the call is over, you can go ahead and register for it, and I'll make you administrator so you've got access. Perfect. And you can go in and start tweaking things. Okay. So once…
Andy Byers: You come at it when you're not logged in, you've basically got your login register buttons up here, you click register, and just follow the registration path there.
Andy Byers: We can log in…
Andy Byers: On this page, you can have a login notice display as well, I'll show you that in a bit, if you want.

Andy Byers: Like, we usually use it for things like… like, when a journal migrates, just to say, you know, we've migrated to a new platform, you know, you might need to reset your password before you can log in, that kind of thing. We usually put a message like that in there.
Andy Byers: So, the other thing you can see is that I've imported all the in-progress articles as well. I'm not sure if these numbers match up with what
Andy Byers: How it's… how you have it.

Andy Byers: Currently, one of the things we need to have a look through is to double-check that the mapping that I've done between Scholastica statuses matches where I've put them in Janeway. I have a map that I can show you that sort of takes a status from Scholastica and maps it to a status in Janeway, but basically…
Andy Byers: We can see now, the reviews, are imported as well. There was one issue as well that cropped up here, was that for completed reviews.
Andy Byers: There's no data.
Andy Byers: in the CSV files to tell us
Andy Byers: What the reviewer submitted. Like, what was their actual review?
Andy Byers: As far as I could see.
Andy Byers: You're on mute at the moment, Meredith, if you're replying.
Meredith Martin: I was. I mean, that lives in Scholastica.
Andy Byers: Hmm.
Meredith Martin: So that's, like, they write it right directly into Scholastic.
Meredith Martin: I was hoping it would be in the CSV export. It should be.
Andy Byers: Let me… I mean, I did have a very…
Andy Byers: relatively in-depth look at it, but I can double-check.
Meredith Martin: Do you want me to show you what it looks like in Scholastica?
Andy Byers: No, I think we just need to… we just need to see it in the CSV, because that's what'll happen in January, so the same thing.
Andy Byers: there'll be a field here with data in it. I'll double-check, maybe I missed one of the CSV files when I was doing the import, but it's not difficult to…
Meredith Martin: It's a template. It's like a Q&A file.
Andy Byers: Okay.
Meredith Martin: I hate that. I think we're gonna get rid of it, but that's what it looks like now.
Andy Byers: Cool. Well, this one also has a revision request, because it was under revision by the author, so we've created the revision request down here as well.
Andy Byers: Some of these articles are… have been hanging around for a while, so we might want to look at archiving them if they're not active, but.
Meredith Martin: Can you show me what that is?
Andy Byers: Yeah, so, I mean, this one here…
Andy Byers: The one at the top is, like, 2020.
Andy Byers: So it may well be that it's been archived in, in Scholastica, but it's in the import, so Janeway's imported it.
Andy Byers: So sometimes.
Meredith Martin: It looks like it was withdrawn.
Andy Byers: Yeah. It's difficult to determine. I couldn't see anything in… for this particular one, because I did look at it, in the decisions that would sort of indicate that it had been…
Andy Byers: withdrawn. There is a field that says it's inactive, and I wonder if maybe that's the field I need to have a look at.
Andy Byers: Scroll down here, I saw it on this page, scroll down.
Meredith Martin: I saw withdrawn, see?
Andy Byers: Oh, that's the… that's the review request.
Meredith Martin: Oh, that's the review request, okay. Huh. What is the title?
Andy Byers: Divergence and the complexity of difference?
Meredith Martin: I mean, it's published.
Andy Byers: Okay.
Andy Byers: So there might be an issue there with some of the CSV data. I'll go back and have a look.
Meredith Martin: So it's right here.
Meredith Martin: And it was published, Volume 5, Issue 2, 2020.
Andy Byers: Quick look.
Andy Byers: Yeah, we've got a published version of it here.
Andy Byers: I have a funny feeling I know exactly what this is, and it's quite a simple solution. There is…
Andy Byers: A disconnect in some of the data.

Andy Byers: from Scholastica, where you have a manuscript, which is an unaccepted file, it's like a new submission that's under review, and then separately you have that, an article. And some of the articles have manuscript IDs to link them together, and some of them don't.
Meredith Martin: So I suspect what's happened here is…

Andy Byers: the manuscript, which we have on… which Jin was imported in to review, is not linked to the published version, so we might just have to do a little bit of data cleanup once we… once we get you guys in. You can tell me which ones you want me to get rid of, and I can just archive them, and they'll just disappear. So that's fine, we can fix that without too much bother.
Andy Byers: Mmm.
Meredith Martin: OS how to archive them so that they just…
Andy Byers: Absolutely, oh, it's… yeah, super easy. So you can go in under Logs, Documents, and more, you can go…
Andy Byers: archive page is the wrong one, it's, Manage Workflow Stage, and you just click Archive.
Meredith Martin: Okay, so that would… that's what we would do if we see another manuscript like this that is… that is disconnected from its published version.

Meredith Martin: But does that mean that the article also has its reviews attached to it still? Yeah, let's double check. It's a duplicate? I'm just… I just don't want to archive it or get rid of it if it's something that's connected to that article.
Andy Byers: Yeah, it doesn't look this has any review data available, but let me double check.
Andy Byers: Yeah, so there's no reviews there. What we might want to do…
Andy Byers: is if I… if I can… I can do a search to see if I can find articles that are in the review stage.

Andy Byers: that also match a title that's got a pub… like, a published version, and we could link them together ourselves in the CSV, and then do… I can do a fresh import with them connected together, and that way…
Meredith Martin: One more time?
Andy Byers: Peter.
Meredith Martin: Say that one more time so I can write it down, so I remember.
Andy Byers: So… what we'll do is… I'll do a search.
Andy Byers: Where I'll match… I'll try and match the articles in review, these ones here.
Meredith Martin: With an article…
Andy Byers: That's in the published stage.
Andy Byers: I'll just try and do a title match, see if there's…
Meredith Martin: Articles with the same title. And where there are…
Andy Byers: we can update the CSV so the manuscript and article in the Scholastica data are linked together.
Meredith Martin: Okay.
Andy Byers: Relatively simple, really, in the grand scheme of things.

Meredith Martin: Right. But that'll keep the data together, so if you're looking at a published article, you can go back and look at the review stage for it, you know? That sounds a lot more efficient than us doing manual data cleaning and manual attention. So let's do that. Okay, great.
Andy Byers: Anyway, so… let's cover… let's go and have a look at the manager.
Andy Byers: So this is basically where you have all the controls, for… and settings for Jangwei, basically.
Andy Byers: Got general settings here, managing peer review, managing submission.
Andy Byers: This lets you play around with some workflow settings. Content is, the CMS, media files, that sort of thing in here, editorial team.
Andy Byers: News managers here. For you guys, I've actually changed it. So it's a blog. I've changed the new system title to blog.
Meredith Martin: Okay. So actually, if we look at the homepage…
Meredith Martin: I think we call it special feature, but yeah, okay, I understand why that is.
Andy Byers: to whatever you want, yeah, that's all fine. And then inside the news manager, you can add posts.
Andy Byers: You can also do start and end display times, so you can have them automatically appear on set days, and disappear on set days, and stuff like that as well.
Meredith Martin: That's great.
Andy Byers: I'll just go back to the manager…
Andy Byers: Article dis- article settings up here…
Andy Byers: This is where identifier stuff is, so you're asking about how DOIs work, and that's over here.
Andy Byers: Okay. And then, Journal.
Meredith Martin: Sorry, can you go back up to the crossroads stuff?
Andy Byers: Yeah.
Meredith Martin: What is the difference between cross-ref and cross-check?

Andy Byers: Yeah, CrossCheck is, is a completely different tool. It's… and the reason for what it is escapes my brain, actually. We implemented it a long time ago. But it's not… it's something to do with Crossref, but it's not, like, DUI minting.
Andy Byers: My brain is not…
Meredith Martin: It's okay, as long as… I mean, I just saw it and was like, oh, is that another thing I have to take care of on my long.
Andy Byers: No, no, I don't think…
Meredith Martin: Okay, well, we can figure it out.
Andy Byers: Yeah, it was the old… this is what it is, I remember now. It's the old name for the plagiarism system.
Meredith Martin: It's, I think.
Andy Byers: authenticate now.
Meredith Martin: Okay, so we'll… oh, got it, I see.
Andy Byers: Yeah.
Meredith Martin: So cross-check settings is authenticate. Okay, great, thank you, that's helpful.
Andy Byers: It's the old name. They changed it 3 times, so, yeah.

Meredith Martin: No, no, it's more… it's more that I saw Crossref, and I… because I'm so trying to keep… I have to migrate all the accounts over from McGill, I saw it and thought, is that a thing I have to do? Is that a username I need to… I need to get that Andy did… that, Andrew Piper didn't tell me about? No, it should be okay.

Andy Byers: User management's down here. We have a new… we have these old legacy systems for user management, enrolled users, enrolled users, roles, but actually we're migrating it all into a single new, interface for managing journal users all in one place.

Andy Byers: So this… this basically has all the features of those other buttons in one place, you don't have to look around for different things, but here you can search for users, you can give them roles, you can see their history, you can actually control them as well, so I can log in as someone else.
Andy Byers: Let's see what they see.
Meredith Martin: So if you log in… so that's another question we had. If you log in as someone else, this is actually for your authors, right?
Andy Byers: It could be for anyone.
Meredith Martin: But, so say… Well, wait a minute, okay.
Meredith Martin: We're in the admin interface right now, though, so, like, an author can't go in and log in and.
Andy Byers: No.
Meredith Martin: Right, so okay, so if the editorial assistant can log in, can she send a message as if she's an editor, like a rejection from one of our emails?
Andy Byers: You have to have super user rights to be able to do it, so it would only be the people that you tell us that you want to have access to this.
Meredith Martin: Okay.
Andy Byers: And it's likely a very limited subset of the group. But the log in and log out are recorded, so when someone hits the control button, we log the person who does the control.
Meredith Martin: Huh.

Andy Byers: And then we know any actions that happen in between there, potentially that person, and then when they log out and release the user, that's recorded as well. So we know actions taken in between those two things that are logged.
Meredith Martin: How many… how many super users can we have?
Andy Byers: As many as you like.

Meredith Martin: Okay, well, I mean, I think having Cecily have the ability to send messages as us, we're worried about her… we would like for her to be able to send rejections as us, because we don't want the rejections to blow back on her, and I think that would be really helpful, so if she can.
Andy Byers: Yeah.
Meredith Martin: Freezer, that would be good.
Andy Byers: Yeah, they can do that, that's fine. You come in here, click Control, and then they're logged in essentially as you. I can actually, if I do it, if I just select a random person.
Andy Byers: It just gives you a warning up here, you're currently working on behalf of, and so I see Janeway as that person would see it.
Meredith Martin: Okay, got it, yeah.
Andy Byers: release, and it takes me back to my old…
Meredith Martin: Yeah.
Andy Byers: account.
Meredith Martin: And we can generate emails that come from our own email from in here once we're in here. Okay.
Andy Byers: Absolutely.
Meredith Martin: Oh, thank you.
Andy Byers: Clear cache, basically empties the cache, so if you…

Andy Byers: Jamway basically has a 5-minute cache, so if you're looking at an article page, and you've updated something, and it doesn't immediately… the update doesn't immediately appear, you can click Clear Cache to empty it. Most of the pages where you make changes to things will automatically clear the cache anyway, but this lets you clear everything out.
Meredith Martin: Scheduled reminders for setting up scheduled reminders, email templates for adding email templates.

Andy Byers: And publication notifications, as well, that you can enable if you want, is a feature whereby users can sign up to receive notifications when new articles are published, so they'll get an email, when a new article is published. This is off by default, but you can turn it on if that's a feature you want.
Meredith Martin: So that is for all authors who've ever published in the journal?

Andy Byers: No, it's… so, I as a user, just as a reader, can say, whenever a new article is published in this journal, send me an email and let me know, and it'll add me to this list of readers on the right-hand side here, and I'll get notifications when new articles come out. And what Janeway does is it collects them together, so if you publish, like, 10 articles in one day, it doesn't send 10 emails, it sends.
Meredith Martin: No, of course, of course. Yeah, so…
Andy Byers: You can enable that if that's something you'd be interested in.
Meredith Martin: Can we add people to the readers list who aren't authors?
Andy Byers: You can be… it can be anyone. Anyone with an account in Janeway can…

Meredith Martin: Oh, I see. Okay, so they have to have an account in Janeway to be considered a reader, because we have a MailChimp… we have, like, a newsletter and a MailChimp account type of thing, and that's how we publicize our publications. Yeah. But to have… to give everyone a Janeway account would be impossible, so, okay.
Andy Byers: Yeah.
Andy Byers: Yeah, I mean, lots of ours use… continue using MailChimp for… and we do, OLH, we use MailChimp, and we can have a sign-up link, in the navbar as well, for.
Meredith Martin: We will.
Andy Byers: that, yeah.
Meredith Martin: Yeah, we would… we would like to have that.

Andy Byers: Cool, so we're gonna go through some of the settings. We'll start with general. So this is literally a list of general settings. It's things like name, description of the journal, the ISSN. So I've gone through, actually, and I've set some of this up for you, so I've grabbed a journal description from the old site, you probably want to update it if you want.
Meredith Martin: We are updating it, yeah.
Andy Byers: So this is the thing, you can… when we're done, you guys can register, I'll give you admin permission, you can come in and start playing around with these settings.
Meredith Martin: Great.
Andy Byers: I've set the journal theme to clarity, which is, this one here.
Meredith Martin: And is that the same one as ING?
Andy Byers: Ingrid, theirs is OLH, so it's, slightly different,
Andy Byers: one of the reasons I'd recommend you go with Clarity is it's gonna have WCAG 2.2 AAA valid VPAT, in about a month's time.
Andy Byers: So if anyone asks you for a accessibility VPAT, we're gonna be able to supply it to them immediately.
Andy Byers: Whereas…
Meredith Martin: We'll go with it.
Andy Byers: Ingrid.
Meredith Martin: We'll go with it. That sounds great. So… Can't, but can Carly make…
Meredith Martin: this template of Clarity look like Ingrid?
Andy Byers: Yeah, she can, yeah.
Meredith Martin: Okay, great. That's fine.
Andy Byers: You can do almost anything, really. It's a very similar layout, actually, to Ingrid.
Meredith Martin: It is.
Andy Byers: Yeah, you've got the logo at the top, the navbar with the bars, and then.
Meredith Martin: and the.

Andy Byers: layout. And I designed this one, this theme myself, basically to take the three existing themes Janeway has and bring them together into one unified theme. That's basically what it is. So it's supposed to look like the others as well.
Meredith Martin: Okay.

Andy Byers: So I've put your publisher details in, I've put the contact info. You can have an external privacy policy link if you want to, but Janeway generates one by default, where I can put our default privacy policy in for you.
Andy Byers: And I'll do that after…

Andy Byers: I'll set the from address. The reply to address is one that you guys should have a think about what you want, so this is, like, if the system generates and sends an email, like a reminder that isn't a person that's sending it, it's just a generic email generated by the system.

Andy Byers: Who do you want the reply to to go to? So, we use an editorial at openthepumps.org, sort of generic address for that reply to, so if Janeway sends an email that's not from a person, it's from a system, when the user hits reply, that goes to the editorial office's joint mailbox.

Meredith Martin: So, the way it works in Scholastica, and this was part of why the discussion feature was so useful, is that we would send a message, and then that email chain would be recorded inside the discussion feature. And so we were getting email notifications, but everything was recorded inside Scholastica. So if I sent a message.

Meredith Martin: to Sarah and was like, who would… who should be a reviewer? She could decline the review and suggest reviewers, but there… and we would get an email notification, but that discussion would be inside Scholastica, so we could stay in Scholastica, get that name of the reviewer right from her…
Meredith Martin: message, and then plug it in. So that's the reason that we want that feature.
Andy Byers: But maybe this is not for internal…

Meredith Martin: discussions. I mean, at the same time, we would write to a review, like, same thing with a reviewer decline, or also an author, except that all those… all those course… all the correspondence would be inside the system, and then just notified?
Meredith Martin: Is that what you're asking? Like, where should the notification address be?
Andy Byers: Yeah, I mean… This one was…
Andy Byers: Maybe it's not so important for you because of the way we're gonna set it up, actually, so it might not be a problem.
Andy Byers: I never think…
Meredith Martin: Like, we have a ProtonMail account. Something like that. We just never use it.
Meredith Martin: And we don't really want to use it, we want to get notified on our regular emails and use this, you know?
Andy Byers: Yeah.
Meredith Martin: The only reason we have the proton is to register our, like, Blue Sky account.
Andy Byers: Okay, that's fine, we can ignore that one then.
Andy Byers: I'll fill in this one. That's fine.
Meredith Martin: But wait, just to go back, so the reply to message, like, I still am confused, like, so if that…
Meredith Martin: What kind of message would get sent to that email?
Andy Byers: It's not… it's not a message that would be sent from Janeway 2, it's…
Andy Byers: So, if Jamie was… like, just for example, let's say, for example, I'm editor, I'm editor A,
Andy Byers: I've assigned you, Meredith, as a reviewer, okay?
Meredith Martin: You haven't…
Andy Byers: Completed your review.
Meredith Martin: Sure.
Andy Byers: busy.
Andy Byers: And January sends you a reminder saying.
Andy Byers: We asked you to do a review, it was due on the 17th.
Andy Byers: Are you able to do it?

Andy Byers: That email isn't sent from a person, so it's not sent from you, it's not sent from me, it's sent by Janeway. So what reply to address should Janeway use when sending that email? That's basically what that question is asking.
Meredith Martin: Okay, so I guess what I can do is look to see what reply to address Scholastica used, but I don't think it used one, I think it was just inside Scholastica.
Andy Byers: Yeah, it'll be… I suspect it'll be using a generic inbox account, yeah. So, that's what I was saying, we can do the same thing, so you don't have to worry about it. We'll set it for you.
Meredith Martin: Okay.
Andy Byers: Yeah.

Andy Byers: I'll fill in the support email, we don't care about switching languages. We have some options here for tracking, so we have Google Analytics, if you want to enable Google Analytics, you can put your code in there.

Andy Byers: And then we have the login notice here, so if you want to put a notice on the login page, you can add that into here. You can do the same on the registration page as well, if you want to add either of those. What I'll do is I'll put our generic login page notice that we put on all the migrating journals into that field for you, and you can change it if you want.
Meredith Martin: Okay, and would that be the place where we would put something like…
Meredith Martin: like, for… like, never mind. This is just… this is just log… everybody's log.
Andy Byers: Just generic login, absolutely generic, yeah. But when we migrate people over.
Andy Byers: We often… we put the message in basically saying, we've migrated accounts from an old platform, and usually, I mean, this happens between OJS and Janeway, and…

Andy Byers: Scholastica and Janeway and, Digital Commons and Janeway, the way passwords are managed in those different platforms are not compatible with them. You can't take a password out of OJS and stick it into Janeway, so people have to reset their passwords, basically. And so we put a little notice saying.
Andy Byers: you know, if you had an account on JCA before, you'll just need to use the reset password. If you don't, you can click the register. Just something very basic like that.
Meredith Martin: Okay.
Andy Byers: So yeah, you can run through the general settings and tweak those.
Andy Byers: Homepage is where we can configure the homepage, so this page here. What I've done is I've added a carousel, I've added the About block, and I've added the blog block.
Meredith Martin: Can we get rid of the carousel if we don't like it?
Andy Byers: Yeah, you can just delete These little buttons down here.
Meredith Martin: I mean…
Andy Byers: You can do whatever.
Meredith Martin: Can we just make it a… can we make it just a static image?
Andy Byers: you can do whatever you like. There's an HTML one here, so you can create an HTML block, and you can just put whatever HTML you like into that one.
Meredith Martin: Okay.
Andy Byers: You put a static image. We have lots of journals who've done similar stuff. Ingrid is one of them.
Meredith Martin: Yeah.
Andy Byers: Yeah.

Andy Byers: So yeah, you can tweak those, you can reorder them, we have popular articles, featured articles, so you can do those, and you can just fiddle around with these, so you can add featured articles and click configure, and it will ask you which featured articles do you want, and you can select them from the list.
Meredith Martin: Can I go over… I'm sorry, I know you have… we were back just on the login, so say it's an author or a board member or something who had an account on Scholastica with us.
Meredith Martin: Is it through their ORCID ID?
Meredith Martin: their… sorry, their org ID that it's gonna… I always say that. Is that gonna be how it knows that they're the same person? Like, how are we gonna be sure that it doesn't duplicate
Meredith Martin: People in the background of the new.
Andy Byers: Yeah, it's email address.
Meredith Martin: Okay, so we have to say, please use the same email address then, right?
Andy Byers: If we've imported them, because they were in the dataset.
Meredith Martin: Yeah.
Andy Byers: over from Scholastica, they'll already be in there.
Meredith Martin: Let's hope.
Andy Byers: So they'll just need to… just need to click reset password.
Meredith Martin: $30 million.
Andy Byers: address in, and it'll go…
Meredith Martin: Okay, okay, okay, okay, thanks.
Andy Byers: No worries.
Andy Byers: Images! So this is where you can load some images in to Janeway. We have the header image, which is this one here. I've used the old logo for the old site.
Andy Byers: We have the default large image…
Andy Byers: I've just put in this green one, you can pick whatever you like.
Andy Byers: Press image… so I've put the CDH logo in the bottom left-hand corner, next to the ISSN and the publication.
Meredith Martin: We're gonna need to add the Schmidt Sciences logo, too.
Andy Byers: It's fine. What you can do is just combine them into one file and upload it.
Andy Byers: The one that…
Andy Byers: that we might want a file for… to this two, actually. One is the cover, so on the issues page…
Andy Byers: We have these cover images for the issues. We can turn them off if you don't want them.
Andy Byers: You might…
Meredith Martin: I don't want them.
Andy Byers: That's fine, we can make it just a list, you know? Yeah. Anishi's list, that's fine, we'll do that.
